Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Professor Campbell is fantastic professor, who really understands the subtle nuances of energy markets.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The game is fun and gets you thinking.

The Electricity Strategy Game was the highlight of the course. It really made us think as if we were in the industry andhad control over our own portfolio of energy generators, and gave us a simplified version of the real world. Making our grades a matter of doing well in a game was also a great way to immerse us in the material.
It was a very broad overview of a lot of topics that I was interested in.
The market simulation, really great.
The Energy Strategy game was my favorite part of the course. It was fun and a great hands on way of learning about the energy industry and some of the economics that are behind energy pricing.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I feel like there needs to be more integration of the lecture material and the electricity strategy game. The lectures were fairly disjointed in the material that they covered, and sometimes they were relevant to the game, and other times, they just went off on random tangents. While all the material was interesting, I was never able to construct a "big picture" of the course material.
Overlap with the Energy Economics class is too significant.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I fulfills a requirement for Undergraduate Scholars Program in Energy Studies
Part of the Energy Studies curriculum. Hoping to gain insight into the energy industry as an economics major.

I am studying policy analysis and would like to specialize in water and energy. However, I know very little about energy, and this course was a good introduction on the energy market and what you can focus on when studying energy.
Energy track at FES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To fulfill a requirement.
To understand how electricity markets work, and unique economics of energy.
The course was part of the energy studies curriculum, and I wanted to take a course about the market side of energy technology.

I am studying policy analysis and wanted to decide if a specialization in energy was a good fit for me. However, I was already planning on taking four courses and didn't want to take another full semester course. Yet, I wanted to take a course that introduced me to energy so I could begin to understand if energy economics and policy interested me. This course was perfect.
Learn more about utilities and how they manage their markets.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes
Yes. There was a good breadth and depth in the information; just could be better integrated into one cohesive syllabus.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working in teams on the game made it interesting.
Advantages were that it split up the work, and new ideas could be brought in.Disadvantages were the differing levels of commitment to the class and the project.
Coordination about who would input the values for the market game was not good.

As an undergraduate, I was paired with an SOM student and a Forestry student for group work, both of whom had more experience and knowledge than I. This was particularly great for me because I was able to do better in the class with their help and was able to learn from them.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: More diverse perspectives.

Try to relate everything you learn the to Electricity Strategy Game. The final is a take-home, and is not the "main concern" of the course. You should try to get the most out of the industry-relevant part of the course.
Not to put too much debate/hard work into the game for the first few days. Just have a solid strategy every game day. Go to all the classes and take good notes.
Take this or Energy Economics, not both.
